admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability is likely, and, institutional development
            impacts are substantial. Lessons suggest that contrary to
            the Operations Evaluation Department's general
            assessment, - that Bank's transport operations, achieve
            better results on physical aspects, than institutional ones
            - this project promoted substantial reform in the
            country's highways sector. Key factors contributing to
            these achievements were the Government's and
            Bank's flexibility in redefining the scope of technical
            assistance (TA) to meet clients needs, and, a sustained
            commitment by the Department of Public Works and Highways to
            pursue a long-term reform consensus, supported by the Bank,
            in addition to: the use of participatory processes to build
            ownership in implementing road management systems, and the
            use of consulting services to assist processing politically
            complex reform initiatives. While civil works faced
            technical, financial, and managerial intervention problems,
            these were overcome by strong ownership, and the adequate
            coordination of the Bank. Nonetheless, it is suggested that
            the civil works program should be fully appraised before
            negotiations; that procurement documents, and TA studies to
            be implemented in the first year program, be finalized at
            approval time; and, that contracts stipulate provisions for
            increasing contractor's performance bond amounts, to
            discourage unrealistic bidding.
